question: How might the DOJâ€™s release of heavily redacted, mostly previously known Epstein documents, coupled with Attorney General Pam Bondiâ€™s demand for thousands of additional files, shape public trust, media narratives, and expectations for any subsequent disclosures?

content.source_1:
A group of conservative influencers left the White House on Thursday afternoon, all holding white binders emblazoned with the Department of Justice seal. Some of them held up the binders to the cameras, which showed that they were labeled â€œThe Epstein Files: Phase 1.â€

The unusual scene came just hours after Attorney General Pam Bondi, who wasconfirmed earlier this month, vowed to release a cache of documents related to the late financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Bondi had promised that the files would include flight logs and the names of individuals involved, but she had cautioned that some information could not be disclosed due to the need to protect more than 250 victims.

Read More:How Longtime Epstein Watchers Reacted to the Release of the â€˜Epstein Filesâ€™

A review of the released documents found that they included heavy redactions and mostly information that had been previously reported. While the binders appeared to be marked â€œdeclassified,â€ questions remained as to whether they had ever been classified in the first place. The limited scope of the release drew criticism from some Republicans, including Rep. Anna Paulina Luna of Florida, who leads a House GOP task force on government transparency.

â€œI nor the task force were given or reviewed the Epstein documents being released today â€¦ A NY Post story just revealed that the documents will simply be Epsteinâ€™s phonebook,â€Luna tweeted. â€œTHIS IS NOT WHAT WE OR THE AMERICAN PEOPLE ASKED FOR and a complete disappointment. GET US THE INFORMATION WE ASKED FOR!â€

Read More:Released â€˜Epstein Filesâ€™ Disappoint Anticipators. A Republican â€˜Rickrollâ€™ Didnâ€™t Help

In a Thursdayletter to FBI Director Kash Patel, Bondi suggested that the FBI had more documents related to Epsteinâ€™s investigation and indictment. She ordered the â€œfull and completeâ€ Epstein files to be delivered to her office by Friday morning, and also ordered Patel to â€œconduct an immediate investigationâ€ as to why her previous order on delivering all the files wasnâ€™t followed.

As the Epstein documents were released, Patelposted on Xthat the bureau is â€œentering a new era.â€ He added: â€œIf there are gaps, we will find them. If records have been hidden, we will uncover them. And we will bring everything we find to the DOJ to be fully assessed and transparently disseminated to the American people as it should be.â€

Among those carrying the binders outside the White House was political commentator Rogan Oâ€™Handley, known online as DC Draino, along with Libs of TikTok creator Chaya Raichik, podcaster Liz Wheeler, and Jack Posobiec, among others. Someposted the same seemingly coordinated messageon X, including the line: â€œThis is the most transparent administration in American history.â€

Bondi discussed the release of the documents in aninterviewwith Fox News on Wednesday, offering a glimpse of what might be includedâ€”though she stopped short of confirming whether new revelations would emerge from the files, beyond what the public already knew. Epsteinâ€™s dark history, marked by his abuse of underage girls, has been extensively documented over the years, with multiple lawsuits, criminal dockets, and public disclosures laying bare the extent of his crimes.

Read More:The Biggest Names from Jeffrey Epsteinâ€™s Unsealed Court Documents

In January 2024, a court unsealed a large batch of documents from the lawsuit filed by Virginia Giuffre, one of Epsteinâ€™s victims. The materials released at that time, including police reports and victim testimonies, had already been publicly circulated.

Epsteinâ€™s predatory behavior spanned more than a decade, with allegations dating back to the 1990s. He was accused of abusing hundreds of children, some as young as 14, in a sprawling operation allegedly involving high-profile individuals, including politicians, celebrities, and royalty. Epsteinâ€™s death in 2019, ruled a suicide while in a Manhattan jail awaiting trial, only fueled conspiracy theories and renewed calls for transparency.
content.source_2:
Andrew Stanton is a Newsweek weekend reporter based in Maine. His role is reporting on U.S. politics and social issues. Andrew joined Newsweek in 2021 from The Boston Globe. He is a graduate of Emerson College. You can get in touch with Andrew by emailinga.stanton@newsweek.com. Languages: English.

Based on facts, either observed and verified firsthand by the reporter, or reported and verified from knowledgeable sources.

Newsweek AI is in beta. Translations may contain inaccuraciesâ€”please refer to the original content.

ğŸ™ï¸ Voice is AI-generated. Inconsistencies may occur.

Attorney GeneralPam Bondihas been made aware of "thousands of documents" related to the investigation intoJeffrey Epsteinthat were previously not disclosed to her office, she said in a letter on Thursday.

Bondi has beenurged by Republican lawmakers to disclose informationabout Epstein, the late financier and convicted sex offender who mingled with some of the world's most influential figures.

Epstein wasarrested in July 2019 on charges of sex traffickingand died by suicide in a New York federal jail a month later while awaiting trial. His former girlfriend and associate,Ghislaine Maxwell,was sentenced in 2022for aiding Epstein in the trafficking of minors and is serving a 20-year prison sentence.

PresidentDonald Trumpcampaigned on releasing the "Epstein list," a rumored document that some people believe may link high-profile individuals to sex crimes. The case has long been a subject of public fascination.

Bondi raised concerns about the documents in a letter toFBIDirectorKash Patelon Thursday. The letter was first reported byFox News.

"I repeatedly questioned whether this was the full set of documents responsive to my request and was repeatedly assured by the FBI that we had received the full set of documents," she wrote. "Late yesterday, l learned from a source that the FBI Field Office in New York was in possession of thousands of pages of documents related to the investigation and indictment of Epstein.

"Despite my repeated requests, the FBI never disclosed the existence of the files. When you and I spoke yesterday, you were just as surprised as I was to learn this new information."

She told Patel that the FBI is to deliver the documents to her office by 8 a.m. Friday, February 28. She also directed Patel to conduct an investigation into why she was not made aware of the files earlier, giving him two weeks to deliver to her a report into his findings.

"There will be no withholdings or limitations to my or your access," she wrote. "TheDepartment of Justicewill ensure that any public disclosure of these files will be done in a manner to protect the privacy of victims and in accordance with law, as I have done my entire career as a prosecutor."

Attorney General Pam Bondi told Fox News on Wednesday:"What you're going to see, hopefully tomorrow, is a lot of flight logs, a lot of names, a lot of information but it's pretty sick what that man did."

Senator Mike Lee, on X, formerly Twitter:"This informationâ€”about Epstein, the Las Vegas shooter, the JFK assassination, etc.â€”belongs to the American people. It's about damn time they be given access to it!"

Bondi has said she wanted to release the documents on Thursday. Earlier in the day, several conservative influencers were seen at the White House carrying binders that read "The Epstein Files," though it isn't clear what was in them.

content.source_3:
WASHINGTON â€” The Justice DepartmentÂ released a handful of files onÂ notorious sex traffickerJeffrey Epsteinon Thursday â€” though there appear to be no new names or details.

The info first went out to a hand-selected crop of right-wing social media influencersÂ ThursdayÂ afternoon â€” and even those recipients were underwhelmed by what the documents revealed.

A source who reviewed the files told The Post ahead of the influencersâ€™ embargoed release that they spanned more than 100 pages of the notorious pedophileâ€™s phone book, including a list of contacts without further context and addresses redacted.

This person addedÂ the unveiling was likely to be a â€œdisappointmentâ€ to sleuths eager for bombshell new evidence aboutÂ Epsteinâ€™sÂ connectionsÂ to prominent political and business leaders.

Indeed, when the conservative social media personalities began livestreaming footage of the content after The Postâ€™s initial report, they revealed files that were long available in the public record â€” such as flight logs â€” and that all of the boldfaced names in the contact list already were known from prior disclosures.

Hours later, Attorney General Pam Bondi released the documents publicly. The namesÂ in the contact book included Michael Jackson, Britainâ€™s Prince Andrew, Mick Jagger, Ethel Kennedy (the mother of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.), Alec Baldwin and former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

However, the document appeared to be a copy of Epsteinâ€™s â€œblack bookâ€ that was first published in 2021 and later put up for auction.

A list of 254 names on another document titled â€œMASSEUSESâ€ was entirely redacted.

The flight logs included in the release were made public as part of Epstein accomplice Ghislaine Maxwellâ€™s 2021 trial.

No â€œclient listâ€Â was included in the release, which was compiled into binders describing the disclosure as â€œphase oneâ€ of the Epstein files, according to The Postâ€™s source.

Bondi later suggested more details will be coming. In a letter to FBI Director Kash Patel made public Thursday afternoon, she claimed she had been told â€œthe FBI Field Office in New York was in possession of thousands of pages of documents related to the investigation and indictment of Epstein.â€

Bondi went on to demand the â€œfull and complete Epstein files to my office, including records, documents, audio and video recordings, and materials related to Jeffrey Epstein and his clientsâ€ by 8 a.m. Friday.

Bondi previously hinted at more dramatic revelations in a Wednesday night interview with Jesse Watters of Fox News, saying she would release â€œa lot of names, a lot of informationÂ â€” itâ€™s pretty sick what that man did.â€

Epsteinâ€™s criminal activities with minors have attracted long-lasting public interest because of his deep connections to the worldâ€™s most powerful men before his downfall â€” including free trips aboardÂ his â€œLolita Expressâ€ jet and stays at his lush private Caribbean island.

Former President Bill Clinton, Bill Gates, Prince Andrew and President Trump are among the high-profile people who associated with Epstein â€” though Trumpreportedly bannedEpsteinÂ from Mar-a-Lago in 2007 over an incident with a club memberâ€™s teen daughter. (Trump was not named in the contact list, though some of his family members were.)

Copies of the binder circulated within the West Wing Thursday morning and were distributed toÂ 15Â conservative influencers who visited the White House.

One of the influencers who obtained early access to the files, podcaster Liz Wheeler, acknowledged that the trove lacked a â€œbombshell.â€

â€œNow whatâ€™s interesting is weâ€™re all waiting for bombshells,â€ Wheeler toldÂ followers in a livestream on X. â€œWeâ€™re all waiting for juicy stuff. And thatâ€™s not whatâ€™s in this binder. Thatâ€™s not whatâ€™s in this binder at all. And thatâ€™s exactly how the attorneyÂ general presented it to us.â€

â€œItâ€™s fine to feel frustrated,â€ she added. â€œYou should feel frustrated.â€

Wheeler briefly showed off portions of the binder, revealing heavily redacted pages, including a contact list, while insisting, â€œwhat we were looking for was hidden from us.â€

Rep. Anna Paulina Luna (R-Fla.), who leads a House GOP task force on government transparency, demanded more information.

â€œI nor the task force were given or reviewed the Epstein documents being released today â€¦ A NY Post story just revealed that the documents will simply be Epsteinâ€™s phonebook,â€Luna tweeted.

â€œTHIS IS NOT WHAT WE OR THE AMERICAN PEOPLE ASKED FOR and a complete disappointment. GET US THE INFORMATION WE ASKED FOR!â€

Some of Epsteinâ€™s address books have already been made public, and itâ€™s unclear if the document dump will include fresh information.

A 97-page address bookpublished by Gawker in 2015included names, addresses and phone numbers of 221 people.

A different address book from 1997 wasput up for auctionlast year but failed to sell.

That 64-page bookÂ listed 349 people including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., NewsNation anchor Chris Cuomoâ€™s wife Cristina Greeven, actress Morgan Fairchild and billionaire Carl Icahn.

Epstein was found dead in his Manhattan jail cell on Aug. 10, 2019, from what authorities deemed a suicide.

At the time, the 66-year-old was awaiting trial on federal sex-trafficking charges.

Maxwell is serving a 20-year prison sentence on charges of child sex trafficking and perjury, among other counts.

A Justice Department spokesman did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
